rows.name: Sarah Cooper
rows.familyremembrance:
Sarah Cooper's address is listed as:
1530 Webster Street, Brooklyn, NY but there is no such address that we've been able to find. There are a Webster Place + Avenue in Brooklyn but far from all other Triangle workers. Webster Avenue in the Bronx is located on the old EL line and near several other Triangle Workers.

rows.name: Rosie Weiner
rows.address: 119 St. Marks Place, New York, NY
rows.familyremembrance:
Remembrance by her great niece Suzanne Pred Bass: On a blustery early spring morning on March 25th 1911, two sisters, Rosie and Katie Weiner, set out for work from their family home at 119 East 8th Street (now St Marks Place). Rosie was nineteen and engaged to be married, Katie was two years younger. Both worked at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory on the 9th floor. This was the end of a long, difficult work week and I can imagine how they must have been anticipating their Saturday night and Sunday break. Only one of them would return home to their mother.
Katie, a vivacious pretty blonde, whose main language was Yiddish, told me how she had grabbed the elevator cable of the last elevator to leave the 9th floor. Her feet landed on the heads of the women in the car as she made it down to safety. Later, Katie testified against the factory owners at their trial.
Exactly what happened to Rosie is unknown. It has always been my idea that Rosie as the older sister felt responsible for Katie and so lost the time she needed to get out searching for her. She and the 145 other mostly young Italian and Jewish immigrant women, filled with hopes and dreams, died tragically and unnecessarily because of corporate greed and cruelty on that day.
Growing up I was fortunate to be told by my mother about my great aunt Katie's escape. It was described as an act of heroism and I was very proud to know Katie and her husband Phil Lubliner, a union president. They were big spirited and big hearted people.
Rosie was not talked about. I think the trauma to the family was so overwhelming that it became too painful to mention. Several relatives I have spoken to were never told about the fire. I am grateful to my Mom for sharing Katie's story with me and understand her desire to protect me as a child from the horror of Rosie's death. When I did learn about Rosie, my mother told me her grandmother (Rosie and Katie's mom) could not bear the loss and died soon after. Only when I was a mother myself did she tell me that she had been taken by her own mother to the morgue to identify Rosie's body.
This cataclysmic loss to my family and to all of the families left holes, sometimes too deep to repair. We can be grateful for the crucial safety and labor reforms that were etched into place because of the fire, and that form a legacy that still includes an enduring commitment to work for a better, safer world.

rows.name: Maria Giuseppa (Tortorelli) Lauletta
